import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

# Create sample agricultural operations data for vegetable crop categories
# Based on typical agricultural patterns and realistic values

# Vegetable crop categories
categories = ['Leafy Vegetables', 'Root Vegetables', 'Fruit Vegetables', 'Legumes', 'Other Vegetables']

# Sample data for 2011 (number of agricultural operations)
# Using realistic patterns: Fruit vegetables typically have more operations due to higher maintenance
# Root vegetables have moderate operations, leafy vegetables have fewer operations
operations_2011 = {
    'Leafy Vegetables': 1250,
    'Root Vegetables': 1850,
    'Fruit Vegetables': 2450,
    'Legumes': 950,
    'Other Vegetables': 1500
}

# Sample data for 2016 (showing growth patterns)
# Assuming overall growth in agricultural operations with some categories growing faster
operations_2016 = {
    'Leafy Vegetables': 1450,  # 16% growth
    'Root Vegetables': 2100,   # 13.5% growth
    'Fruit Vegetables': 2850,  # 16.3% growth
    'Legumes': 1100,           # 15.8% growth
    'Other Vegetables': 1750   # 16.7% growth
}

# Create DataFrames for better data management
df_2011 = pd.DataFrame({
    'Category': categories,
    'Operations': [operations_2011[cat] for cat in categories]
})

df_2016 = pd.DataFrame({
    'Category': categories,
    'Operations': [operations_2016[cat] for cat in categories]
})

print("Sample Agricultural Operations Data")
print("=" * 50)
print("\n2011 Data:")
print(df_2011)
print(f"\nTotal Operations in 2011: {sum(operations_2011.values()):,}")

print("\n2016 Data:")
print(df_2016)
print(f"\nTotal Operations in 2016: {sum(operations_2016.values()):,}")

# Calculate growth rates
growth_rates = {}
for category in categories:
    growth = ((operations_2016[category] - operations_2011[category]) / operations_2011[category]) * 100
    growth_rates[category] = growth

print("\nGrowth Rates (2011-2016):")
for category, rate in growth_rates.items():
    print(f"{category}: {rate:.1f}%")

args.code:
# Create the pie chart for 2011 data
plt.figure(figsize=(12, 8))

# Pie chart for 2011
plt.subplot(1, 2, 1)
colors = ['#ff9999', '#66b3ff', '#99ff99', '#ffcc99', '#c2c2f0']
wedges, texts, autotexts = plt.pie(
    df_2011['Operations'], 
    labels=df_2011['Category'], 
    autopct='%1.1f%%',
    colors=colors,
    startangle=90,
    textprops={'fontsize': 10}
)

# Improve the appearance
plt.setp(autotexts, size=10, weight="bold")
plt.title('Agricultural Operations by Vegetable Category (2011)\nTotal Operations: 8,000', 
          fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)

# Bar chart for 2016
plt.subplot(1, 2, 2)
bars = plt.bar(df_2016['Category'], df_2016['Operations'], color=colors, alpha=0.7)
plt.title('Agricultural Operations by Vegetable Category (2016)\nTotal Operations: 9,250', 
          fontsize=14, fontweight='bold', pad=20)
plt.xlabel('Vegetable Category', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Number of Operations', fontsize=12)
plt.xticks(rotation=45, ha='right')

# Add value labels on bars
for bar in bars:
    height = bar.get_height()
    plt.text(bar.get_x() + bar.get_width()/2., height + 30,
             f'{int(height):,}', ha='center', va='bottom', fontsize=10)

plt.tight_layout()
plt.show()

print("\nVisualizations created successfully!")
